title: Australia's new casino but you wouldn't know it
text:
Destination Brisbane Consortium – which includes the Star group, developers Far East Consortium and Hong Kong-based Chow Tai Fook – use similar phrases and terms to promote the development. Casino isn't one of them.

Instead, banners draped over hundreds of metres around the construction site contain buzz phrases about bars and apartments.

It's more politically palatable to be saying you're promoting tourism and building a resort, rather than a casino. — Stephen Mayne, anti-gambling campaigner

The consortium’s home internet page about the project does not use the word casino. References to gaming are found deeper in the website. The sole gambling reference in a 3.02-minute promotional video on the main page is when the words “VIP Sky Gaming” appear for three seconds.

“It's a joke. It's a casino. It's pretty cynical and completely disingenuous,” anti-gambling campaigner Stephen Mayne said.

“It's a straight marketing ploy. It's more politically palatable to be saying you're promoting tourism and building a resort, rather than a casino.”

Star is paying $1 billion to the Queensland government over the next 15 years as part of the development, which has taken up half a dozen blocks of prime real estate on the Brisbane River's northern banks.

Star, whose annual shareholder meeting will be held on Thursday, is transferring the licence over from its existing Brisbane Treasury casino. But there is a 53 per cent increase in allowable poker machines – from 1632 to 2500.

Advertisement

It earned 80 per cent of its $721 million in Queensland domestic revenue from gaming last financial year.

Mr Mayne said the term “integrated resort” – which the government and consortium were using – had become a code word for a casino and hotel development. It was also crucial in marketing the development in China, where the promotion of gambling is illegal.

“The integrated resort model was used in Singapore and it absolutely boomed. Other places are trying to not be so overt [about gambling] ... it's the model everyone is using,” he said.

Don't mention the "c" word ... an artist's impression of Brisbane's planned $3.6 billion Queen Wharf resort complex. Destination Brisbane Consortium

Daniel Angus, of QUT’s Creative Industries Faculty, which counts linguistics among its specialities, said a “second language” could be created around certain vice products, such as alcohol or gambling.

That was to disassociate the new words from negative connotations tied to terms such as gambling. “They’re loaded terms,” he said.

Mr Angus, who travels past the project's banners on the river's edge, said there wasn't “a single picture of a gaming machine”.

Adam Ferrier, a marketing expert who founded agency Thinkerbell, said casino operators might highlight aspects of the project other than gaming to dial-up different revenue-generating activities.

Advertisement

“They’re selling the image of an aspirational lifestyle … or a night out,” he said.

It made the image more “socially acceptable” than merely sitting around a gambling table, Mr Ferrier said. But people would still be aware “there’s a casino in town”, he added.

A Financial Review survey of government media statements discussing the project found that the last reference to it being a casino was in December 2017, while another in November last year used the term only in passing because an event was held at “Treasury Casino”.

Bridges and cranes

There have been at least eight other statements since then about the project. At least seven mentioned the 50 bars and restaurants on the site and five mentioned a new bridge. Even the word “crane” appeared more often than casino.

That contrasted with earlier messaging on the project. In April 2016, Training and Skills Minister Yvette D’Ath made multiple references to its function as a casino in an announcement about new laws for the development.

Destination Brisbane Consortium declined to answer questions but said the development would deliver significant economic benefits, and drive “dramatic” increases in interstate and international visitation.“There will be a casino in the integrated resort that replaces the existing Treasury casino ... Brisbane remains a one-casino city,” a spokesman said.

The Queensland government had not responded to questions.
description: What casino? The Queensland government and the consortium building a new $3.6b development have a hard time saying the casino is its centrepiece.
